title: Mums are joining one of the UK's most extreme clubs to tackle 'female guilt'
text:

They're mums, wives and ordinary women - but they all have one thing in common.

These ladies are members of the UK's most extreme all-female running club.

Many hadn't pounded the streets until recently but now they're prepering to take on as life-changing challenge.

And they want to get more women involved in a bid to tackle 'female guilt' through the amazing feat of endurance running.

Founded by 37-year-old Allie Bailey, a freelance marketing manager from Somerset, female First hopes to inspire more women to take part.

In her spare time Allie is a race explorer and ‘test pilot’ for UK firm Rat Race Adventure Sports, who host events across the world.

And now she has headed to Scotland to for a full traverse of the Outer Hebrides.

Along with her crack team of fellow female runners she will cover 185 miles in five days, racking-up an average of 37 miles of running per day while ferry-hopping between the islands.

Allie hopes the project will help tackle the ‘female guilt’ many mums feel when they spend time away from their families.

She said: “Many of the women I talk to don’t think they are strong enough, fast enough or fit enough to try an adventure race. They worry about holding the rest of the team back.

“Female guilt plays a part - they don’t feel like they can take a small amount of time out away from their families to do something for themselves, something that will ultimately make them physically and mentally stronger, happier and more resilient.

“I want to help encourage and inspire more women to get out and push their limits.”

The team set out from Barra and will run to the Butt of Lewis via South Uist, Benbecula, North Uist, Harris and Lewis, finishing on October 18.

(Image: xxxxxxxxxxx)

They will tackle mountains, beaches and peat bogs along the way.

Allie Bailey, is 37-year-old freelance marketing manager who lives in Somerset

“Don’t celebrate the win, celebrate the experience."

Allie, who took up running eight years ago.

She was struggling with depression, and having tried to take her own life, a doctor recommended running as a means to lift the black cloud that hovered above her.

Since 2017, and on the back for a mental setback, Allie has undertaken some of the most demanding challenges the world has to offer.

Last year she completed the first ever foot crossing of an uninhabited stretch of the Namib Desert, covering 127 miles in four days and ascending half the height of Everest.

Just days after that feat, she and other Rat Race test pilots blazed a new coast-to-coast trail through the jungles of Panama, covering 125 miles - and 29,0000 ft of ascent - in six days.

Now she’s on a mission to convince more women they can follow in her muddy footsteps

She said: “Every time I get to the airport, or the start line of a big race, I get the realisation that I am either the only woman there, or one of a small handful.

(Image: xxxxxxxxxxx)

“It can be heartbreaking to think that there are people sat at home, wishing that they could do this stuff, but not having the confidence to give it a go.

“I want to help those people realise their dreams. Rat Race is so inclusive in what they do, and encourage people from all walks of life to take part in.

“They don’t celebrate the win, they celebrate the experience. I want women to be able to believe in more - to be able to see the world and come back empowered and confident.

“I’m hoping between Ultra Awesome and Rat Race we can create a 50/50 gender split on the start lines of some amazing experiences.”

And here are the other ordinary women taking on the extraordinary challenge.

Kim Hopkinson, is 30-year-old Senior Business Development Officer for charity Change, Grow, Live, and lives in Banbury, Oxfordshire, with husband Jack.

She said: “I want to leave this trip with the realisation that stuff like this is for ordinary people like me.”

Kim only took up running four years ago.

But she has graduated from brief mile-and-a-half runs under the cover of darkness - to spare any blushes about her fitness levels - to marathon distances, including a 34 mile trek last year.

She said: “Running is simple, but it’s also very visible when you’re a woman running on the streets.

“So I would go out in the dark, in a million layers, on a quiet route from my house.

“I always thought it was really long way but looking back it was quite short - around a mile and a half.

“But just going out running a couple of times a week, you can improve so quickly.

“This year I did London Marathon... and absolutely hated it. It was too busy, too loud, and I felt like just a number. I craved something different - and that’s where adventure racing has come in.”

For Kim, camaraderie is key.

She added: “It’s not a race, we’re all in this together.

“And I want to leave this trip with the realisation that stuff like this is for ordinary people like me.”

Gillian McColl, is 46-year-old director of an electrical contractor company from Kinross, Scotland, and a mum of two children - Adam, nine, and Alicia, eight.

She said: “I’m not selfish - time away on adventures makes me a happier person and a better mother.”

Gillian is an experienced runner and has completed a number of marathons and ultras - but only really started running seriously in 2016, having become a mother to two children in 2010 and 2011.

In June this year she completed the The Spine Race, covering 108 miles, non-stop, in just 40 hours.

And yet her passion for adventure running has seen her experiencing negative comments from school-run mums.

She said: “I used to feel really guilty about going out for runs when I first started running again after becoming a mum, and that wasn’t helped by some of the comments I received from mums at the school gate.

“I had one telling me, ‘you must be really selfish to take all that time out for yourself - do you not feel bad about that?’

“I was shocked, and found myself questioning, ‘Am I being selfish?’

“After some introspection I realised that running makes me a healthier, better person. I need time-out to clear my head and this makes me a better mum.

“I don’t actually care what people think anymore, because this sport works for me and it works for my family.

(Image: xxxxxxxxxxx)

“You can’t be a 24 hour-a-day mother. You have to have your own ‘thing’ - your stress release that helps you cope with the demands of work.

“Besides, the children love telling their friends about events that I’m doing as they think the distances I run are a bit crazy.

“And I want them to see what is possible when you try and push yourself out of your comfort zone.

"If you had told me three years ago that I could have run a marathon never mind an ultra I think I would have laughed!”

Laura Fisher, is a 43-year-old mother of three and lives near Faversham, Kent.

She said: “I grew up thinking I hated running.”

Laura was another late starter - only getting into fitness five years ago.

She loved boot-camp style classes - but always ‘hated’ running, viewing it as a ‘necessary evil’.

But when she tried obstacle course racing, she caught the bug, and the running distances got longer and longer.

For Laura - mum to George 14, Margot 11 and Emmanuel nine - it’s the purity of the journey that holds so much appeal.

She said: “Friends would talk about how wonderful running was, how it cleared the mind and helped them solve their day-to-day problems, but I never got that at all. I just used to think, ‘When can I stop?’ and, ‘Am I going to die?’.

“But since realising that running was actually something I enjoy, I've done countless obstacle and road races - everything from 5Km to marathon distance.

“The unimportant, mundane things we all worry about in life start to fall away and I focus entirely on the journey.”

Meanwhile Laura says running isn’t about getting the perfect body, either.

She added: “I’m 43 and I run for fitness, yes, but my motivating factors are not to lose weight or achieve a certain body type – I’m far more interested in testing by body to see what I can achieve.

"A smaller waistline is an added bonus but not what gets me lacing up my running trainers.

“I’m also determined to instil the idea in my kids that if you really want something you can achieve it.

"But to make this achievement you need to work - and that can be damn hard, simply wanting something is not enough.”

Alice Kirk, is a 54-year-old psychotherapist who specialises in bereavement with couples and families, lives in rural Derbyshire, with her husband and three teenage daughters.

She said: “I don’t want to be an observer.”

After losing her husband when she was 28, former marketing manager Alice retrained as a psychotherapist.

And despite having been a runner most of her life, she only started taking on ‘ultra’ distances - anything more than a marathon in length - around five years ago.

She said: “After a difficult period in my life about five years ago, a conversation with an ultra runner encouraged me to see if I could go further and I entered my first ultra, January 1st 2015.

“Since then, I have taken part in thirty four ultra events.”

For Alice, running takes her into an almost hypnotic, stress-free state, away from the dramas of everyday life.

She added: “When you’re running, your brain becomes completely focused.

“It’s amplified when you’re covering long distances, too. You kind of go into this numb state, where the only thing you think about is the next checkpoint.

“You’re completely separated from anything else that might be worrying you.”

Though Alice says she’s not the fastest runner she likes to invest the time in doing things that others are perhaps too scared to try.

She added: “I don’t want to be an observer.

“I want to be in there, challenging myself. Some people might assume that they can’t do such things, but the only limitations are those you place on yourself.

“I am definitely not a talented runner. I am an ordinary mum of three teenagers and I am pretty slow now compared to my thirties, when I could knock out a decent marathon.

“But running has kept me going through the roughest times in my life. It has been my constant companion. When there was nothing else, I could always go for a run.”
